instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PPBUSS_G3H: What is PPBUSS_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PPBUSS_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no bklt but 10v at f9700
threads.message: Hi I have a issue with this board I have checked g3h in a few different area it 11.5v I have a green light on charger and it chimes. But no backlight

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no bklt but 10v at f9700
threads.message: I?ve tested with a known good screen and I have backlight on keyboard but not screen :/ checked feedback. area no liquid damage anywhere

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no bklt but 10v at f9700
threads.message:
"I have checked g3h in a few different area it 11.5v"
Please post what exactly measure on a board.
You are the first interested to post clear information!

I hope it is not <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.
And if is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is also bad value; if battery is not connected.
F9700 also means <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, so I don't understand how can you get 11.5V and 10V at same line...

I hope you already confirmed image on internal LCD.
Why would search for backlight, if not?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no bklt but 10v at f9700
threads.message: Ok it?s up and running thanks 2informaticos

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no bklt but 10v at f9700
threads.message: One question I clean my boards with just alcohol bath. Since I don?t do this repair for a living Buying a crest ultrasonic seems out of my reach. What is the best method besides ultrasonic to clean them?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no bklt but 10v at f9700
threads.message:
To clean small areas, after changing pieces, use tootbrush and IPA.
Ultrasonic bath is only needed when you have large areas corroded, or accumulated crap under BGA chips.

BTW, which was your solution in this case.
It could help someone else in the future...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chime no bklt but 10v at f9700
threads.message: I?m sorry. it was weird im not sure I?m explaining it right a capacitor <CAPACITOR>C9435</CAPACITOR> although it wasn?t a complete short it was bringing down <SIGNAL>PPBUSS_G3H</SIGNAL> And resistor <RESISTOR>R4650</RESISTOR> for mux after that all the voltages where normalized. Everything just worked
